    Introduction to oec

    Mauricio Vargas S.

    2018-07-18

    oec.Rmd

    The Observatory of Economic Complexity is the world’s leading visualization engine for international trade data. oec provides an easy way to obtain data from the OEC by accessing its API.

    Using the oec R package is all about efficiency, without this package you could obtain the same data from the API at the expense of using additional time and effort for the same results. As an API wrapper and utility program this package makes data obtaining faster and easier for you.

    This is what the package does:

    Package data

    Country codes

    If you don’t know a certain country code you can explore this data before using the functions.

    library(oec)

country_codes
#> # A tibble: 264 x 2
#>    country             country_code
#>    <chr>               <chr>       
#>  1 Afghanistan         afg         
#>  2 Albania             alb         
#>  3 Algeria             dza         
#>  4 American Samoa      asm         
#>  5 Andorra             and         
#>  6 Angola              ago         
#>  7 Anguilla            aia         
#>  8 Antarctica          ata         
#>  9 Antigua and Barbuda atg         
#> 10 Areas               xxa         
#> # ... with 254 more rows

    Product codes

    The OEC provides data classified using either HS92, HS96, HS02 and HS07 (Harmonized System) or SITC rev. 2 (Standard International Trade Classification).

    As UN Comtrade explains both HS and SITC are trade classifications that are updated by releasing new revisions, and when a classification is released then it remains unaltered. For example, HS92 was released in 1992 and its product codes remain unaltered until today, while newer classifications (e.g. HS07) were created to include newer products (e.g. it was important to provide more details about electronic products that did not exist when HS92 was created).

    The only difference between the OEC and official HS/SITC product names is that the OEC provides shortened product names (e.g. under SITC 6821 stands for “Copper and copper alloys, refined or not, unwrought” which we can simplify to “Copper (unwrought)”).

    Each of these classifications consists in numeric codes and a detailed product name associated to each code, for example HS92 (and all HS revisions) contain 4 and 6 digits long codes while SITC does only cointain 4 digits long codes:

    hs92
#> # A tibble: 6,282 x 5
#>    product_name                       id     group_name    group_id color 
#>    <chr>                              <chr>  <chr>         <chr>    <chr> 
#>  1 Horses                             0101   Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  2 Horses, live pure-bred breeding    010111 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  3 Horses, live except pure-bred bre… 010119 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  4 Asses, mules and hinnies, live     010120 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  5 Bovine                             0102   Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  6 Bovine animals, live pure-bred br… 010210 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  7 Bovine animals, live, except pure… 010290 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  8 Pigs                               0103   Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#>  9 Swine, live pure-bred breeding     010310 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#> 10 Swine, live except pure-bred bree… 010391 Animal Produ… 01       #FFE9…
#> # ... with 6,272 more rows

    Each product belongs to a group and the color column (given after product groups) allows to use the same palettes as the official website.

    Package functions

    get_data

    This function downloads data for a single year and needs (at least) a pairs of countries and a valid year according to the trade classification.

    The API returns data for different trade classifications: (i) SITC (1962-2016); (ii) HS92 (1992-2016); (iii) HS96 (1996-2016); (iv) HS02 (2002-2016); (v) HS07 (2007-2016).

    Correct input

    Chile-Argentina bilateral trade data in 2015 (SITC):

    # What does Chile exchange with Argentina?  
# year 2015 - SITC (4 characters)
get_data("chl", "arg", 2015)
#> 
#> Processing 2015 data...
#> # A tibble: 604 x 31
#>     year origin_id destination_id origin_name destination_name id   
#>    <dbl> <chr>     <chr>          <chr>       <chr>            <chr>
#>  1  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        5722 
#>  2  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6251 
#>  3  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6282 
#>  4  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6289 
#>  5  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6352 
#>  6  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6418 
#>  7  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6572 
#>  8  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6577 
#>  9  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6631 
#> 10  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        6632 
#> # ... with 594 more rows, and 25 more variables: id_len <int>,
#> #   product_name <chr>, group_id <chr>, group_name <chr>,
#> #   export_val <dbl>, export_val_growth_pct <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>, export_val_growth_val <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>, export_rca <dbl>, import_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct <dbl>, import_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_val <dbl>, import_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_rca <dbl>, trade_exchange_val <dbl>, pci <dbl>, pci_rank <dbl>,
#> #   pci_rank_delta <dbl>, top_exporter_code <chr>,
#> #   top_importer_code <chr>, top_importer <chr>, top_exporter <chr>,
#> #   color <chr>

    For the other classifications is similar:

    # What does Chile exchange with Argentina?  
# year 2015 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
get_data("chl", "arg", 2015, "hs07")
#> 
#> Processing 2015 data...
#> # A tibble: 3,315 x 31
#>     year origin_id destination_id origin_name destination_name id    
#>    <dbl> <chr>     <chr>          <chr>       <chr>            <chr> 
#>  1  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0101  
#>  2  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010110
#>  3  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010190
#>  4  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0106  
#>  5  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010619
#>  6  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0201  
#>  7  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        020130
#>  8  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0202  
#>  9  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        020230
#> 10  2015 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0206  
#> # ... with 3,305 more rows, and 25 more variables: id_len <int>,
#> #   product_name <chr>, group_id <chr>, group_name <chr>,
#> #   export_val <dbl>, export_val_growth_pct <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>, export_val_growth_val <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>, export_rca <dbl>, import_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct <dbl>, import_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_val <dbl>, import_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_rca <dbl>, trade_exchange_val <dbl>, pci <dbl>, pci_rank <dbl>,
#> #   pci_rank_delta <dbl>, top_exporter_code <chr>,
#> #   top_importer_code <chr>, top_importer <chr>, top_exporter <chr>,
#> #   color <chr>

    If you need data for more than one year you can write the years as a vector:

    # What does Chile exchange with Argentina?  
# years 2010 and 2015 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
get_data("chl", "arg", c(2010,2015), "hs07")
#> 
#> Processing 2010 data...
#> Processing 2015 data...
#> # A tibble: 28,464 x 31
#>     year origin_id destination_id origin_name destination_name id    
#>    <dbl> <chr>     <chr>          <chr>       <chr>            <chr> 
#>  1  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0101  
#>  2  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0101  
#>  3  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0101  
#>  4  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        0101  
#>  5  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010110
#>  6  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010110
#>  7  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010110
#>  8  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010110
#>  9  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010190
#> 10  2010 chl       arg            Chile       Argentina        010190
#> # ... with 28,454 more rows, and 25 more variables: id_len <int>,
#> #   product_name <chr>, group_id <chr>, group_name <chr>,
#> #   export_val <dbl>, export_val_growth_pct <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val <dbl>, export_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>, export_rca <dbl>, import_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct <dbl>, import_val_growth_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>, import_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_rca <dbl>, trade_exchange_val <dbl>, pci <dbl>, pci_rank <dbl>,
#> #   pci_rank_delta <dbl>, top_exporter_code <chr>,
#> #   top_importer_code <chr>, top_importer <chr>, top_exporter <chr>,
#> #   color <chr>

    Incorrect input

    Chile-Argentina bilateral trade data in 2000 (HS02):

    # What does Chile exchange with Argentina?  
# year 2000 - HS02 (4 and 6 characters)
get_data("chl", "arg", 2000, "hs02")
#> Error in get_data("chl", "arg", 2000, "hs02"): Provided that you requested HS02 data please
#>          verify that the data you are requesting is
#>          contained within the years 2002-2016.

    The problem here is that HS02 data is only available since 2002.

    Special cases

    Andorra-France bilateral trade data in 2015 (SITC):

    # What does Andorra exchange with France?  
# year 2015 - SITC (4 characters)
get_data("and", "fra", 2015)
#> 
#> Processing 2015 data...
#> Error in get_data("and", "fra", 2015): No data available. Try changing years or trade classification.

    The problem here is that Andorra did not report SITC data in 2015 but they reported HS07 data.

    Andorra-France bilateral trade data in 2015 (HS07):

    # What does Andorra exchange with France?  
# year 2015 - HS07 (4 and 6 characters)
get_data("and", "fra", 2015, "hs07")
#> 
#> Processing 2015 data...
#> # A tibble: 1,883 x 31
#>     year origin_id destination_id origin_name destination_name id    
#>    <dbl> <chr>     <chr>          <chr>       <chr>            <chr> 
#>  1  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           0101  
#>  2  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           010190
#>  3  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           0102  
#>  4  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           010210
#>  5  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           0106  
#>  6  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           010690
#>  7  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           0201  
#>  8  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           020110
#>  9  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           020120
#> 10  2015 and       fra            Andorra     France           020130
#> # ... with 1,873 more rows, and 25 more variables: id_len <int>,
#> #   product_name <chr>, group_id <chr>, group_name <chr>,
#> #   export_val <dbl>, export_val_growth_pct <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val <dbl>, export_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>,
#> #   export_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>, export_rca <dbl>, import_val <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_pct <dbl>, import_val_growth_pct_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_val_growth_val <dbl>, import_val_growth_val_5 <dbl>,
#> #   import_rca <dbl>, trade_exchange_val <dbl>, pci <dbl>, pci_rank <dbl>,
#> #   pci_rank_delta <dbl>, top_exporter_code <chr>,
#> #   top_importer_code <chr>, top_importer <chr>, top_exporter <chr>,
#> #   color <chr>

    The OEC has some situations as the example above. Not all countries report their trade numbers using all trade classifications.
